title: artist cornflake work sells for 900
story: Anne Griffiths pinned 84 flakes from 11 brands in gem boxes and put them in a glass cabinet.She says Taxonomy of the Cornflake explores how the way an item is displayed changes our value of it.Anne, 54, said: “They’re amazing shapes and variations. Each is unique. Once something’s in a display cabinet with a number, people become interested.“How it’s displayed affects what we consider precious.”Anne, from Wantage, Oxfordshire, numbered each flake based on shape, colour and brand. Her work, on show at London’s Royal Academy of Arts, was inspired by a love of “collecting ridiculous things like lolly sticks and old bulbs”.She can now even tell various flakes apart — but still prefers marmalade on toast at breakfast.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: missiles carriers jets waste of cash
story: It is not important whether this latest story is true in detail, because the fundamentals have been plain for months: Britain’s defences are grossly underfunded, and the responsible minister is attempting to raise dust about it.Williamson is unlikely to secure a boost to match that promised to the NHS last week, for the good reason that nobody likes him, and the bad one that voters care hugely about health, scarcely at all about defence.If the mad idea of hypothecated taxes — money raised to fulfil explicit purposes — ever catches on, nurses will be ­driving Jaguars while generals ride bicycles.As the last of the generation that fought the Second World War dies off, and those who remember the Cold War qualify for pensions, younger British people display little interest in the Armed Forces, save to add colour to royal weddings.They would need a lot of convincing that any war is worth fighting, anywhere.Money spent on defence quickly adds up to eye-watering sums.Threats changing at awesome speedPhilip Hammond, characteristically of a top-class accountant, during his tenure as Defence Secretary achieved miracles in concealing from the nation the desperate financial plight of the Armed Forces, while making little attempt to remedy it.Sir Michael Fallon, his ­successor, subjected senior ­officers to a reign of terror to prevent them from admitting any portion of the truth to ­Parliament or the media, but declined to extend his remit to intimidating the Queen’s ­enemies.Gavin Williamson has become the first Defence Secretary for decades with aspirations to use the post as a springboard to Downing Street. These are likely to go unfulfilled, because he flaunts them so crassly.Yet before acknowledging that the Armed Forces need more money, which they do, we should recognise how hard it is to configure Britain’s defence and security posture at a time when threats and the means to address them are changing at awesome speed.Countering terrorism in some ways represents the least ­difficult element, because it is the only peril the public really cares about.It is evident to all save ­disciples of Julian Assange that electronic surveillance through GCHQ, supported by the intelligence services, armed police and military special forces, deserves generous funding, which it nowadays receives.It is much more difficult to identify the appropriate tools with which to equip the Armed Forces to meet the strategic threats, of which Russia ­represents the most obvious.When President Putin favours hybrid warfare embracing covert special forces, fake news, cyber attacks and subversion, are tanks and infantry battalions the appropriate responses?When US backing for Nato is wavering and key nations such as Germany forswear a serious combat capability, alongside what allies can we hope to present a common front?These are big and hard ­questions.A couple of months ago at a round-table dinner, some of Britain’s top generals and ­strategic gurus held forth about the threats as they see them.Afterwards, the former Defence Secretary Michael Heseltine, who was among the guests, told me that he had been disappointed by the ­unoriginality of the ideas expressed.Here were the brightest and best in the war studies ­universe, he suggested, still thinking inside the parameters of the familiar, when much that is unfamiliar is evolving all around us.In planning for the future, Army commanders deserve sympathy, because they are compelled to observe ­constraints imposed by public sentimentality, to which ­ministers make obeisance.For instance, the chronically under-recruited Scottish regiments should be reduced, instead of having their ranks filled with Fijians (yes, really), but that is politically unthinkable.Nobody dares to axe a foot guards battalion, because the Guards Division remains a powerful trades union.The Gurkhas, whose infrastructure and dependants’ costs now make them uneconomic, cannot be touched because no minister will risk Joanna ­Lumley once more taking to the streets on their behalf. ­Politicians, in their own defence, are entitled to point out that the leaders of the Armed Forces are often poor judges of strategic planning.The admirals of two decades ago begged, fought and pleaded for the Navy’s two preposterous carriers, which I have compared to the Egyptian pyramids — huge consumers of resources for negligible practical utility.It was always obvious that the F-35 aircraft for which they were designed are properly unaffordable by modern Britain.Beyond being described by Americans as “the planes that ate the Pentagon” because of their fantastic cost, recent assessments show them ­performing poorly in the key ground attack role, as do the RAF’s Typhoons, conceived as high-altitude interceptors.Moreover, it was always plain that almost the entire Royal Navy’s residual strength will be required to escort the carriers on active service, while they are incapable of inshore operation.A strong government and Defence Secretary would mothball the behemoths in a display of courage such as was last shown by Denis Healey in 1968 when he decided to withdraw British forces from east of Suez.Forces need more of almost everythingThey would also scrap the Trident deterrent replacement, again a big willy gesture for a little willy nation, inappropriate to our diminished status in the world.I know almost no one whom I respect in the defence loop — military or civilian — who favours trying to sustain a nuclear capability on the ­Trident scale.More money must be found to recruit, train and exercise a credible Army.The only certainty about ­Britain’s defence needs is that more soldiers are wanted, to meet a range of future threats.Something much more serious than the fanatics of IS could well confront Britain in the coming decades.American military friends often remind me that Britain’s Armed Forces today command respect neither from friends nor foes.I remember General Sir Mike Jackson saying ­ruefully, as head of the Army 12 years ago: “Mass matters, and we don’t have it.”Our rulers may sometimes be forgiven for lying to us, but should never be forgiven for lying to themselves, as ­members of this Government do repeatedly.Bits of Britain’s Armed Forces are still superb, but it will not do for ministers merely to keep reciting the tired mantra about how terrific the SAS is.This is a niche force, no more capable of frightening Russia or China than the England cricket team.Gavin Williamson is dead right, that our Armed Forces need more of almost everything.Such a pity, then, that he himself has no more credibility at Westminster than an England cricket coach.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: endurance swimmer lewis pugh to tackle length of english channel
story: On his route, the campaigner and UN Patron of the Oceans will meet people to carry out beach cleans, organised by Surfers Against Sewage.Pugh, 48, is also inviting people to join him for sections of the swim and be a "voice for clean and healthy seas".He said: "I've been swimming in the world's oceans for 30 years. This is not a long time in ecological terms, and yet I've seen the oceans change before my eyes."I am swimming the length of the English Channel to call on the British government to urgently protect the waters that surround the UK."Pugh is calling for the introduction of marine protected areas (MPAs) where wildlife and habitats are protected from human activity.He added: "It has been shown that fully protected marine protected areas give distressed and degraded seas their best chance of recovery.Pugh's swim will be authenticated by The Channel Swimming Association. He will average five hours and 10-20km (six to 12m) per day.He has been training in the cold waters off South Africa, swimming an average of 7km (four miles) a day.He has put on weight to prepare for the challenge, saying the cold and exhaustion will be his biggest challenges.He added: "There will be bad-weather days when I simply won't be able to swim."The English Channel also has very strong tides. I've got to get the timing right, or I could be going backwards."This is not Pugh's first big challenge. He has previously swum in the Arctic and in the waters of South Georgia, in the south Atlantic.:: The Long Swim will be on Sky News on Monday 9 July at 8.30pm

title: facing their fate on the us mexico border
story: Inside, I open the doors to a large courtroom. I am stunned by what I see. I count 64 men and nine women - all in prison chains.Most seem to be in their twenties. There is an expectant, quiet din in the air.In the corners of the room, lawyers are trying to brief them on their rights and explain the legal process.Here, it is rapid. In a matter of minutes, large groups of defendants will stand up, issue their plea and face their fate.In an office upstairs, Judge Bernardo Velasco tries to explain his dizzying workload."I will see seven people with seven lawyers standing in front of the court in front of microphones," he said."The process will take anything from two or three minutes to 10 or 15 minutes depending on the judge." But confusion reigns over the policy.He tells me that recently defendants who have been separated from their children have asked about the whereabouts of their children."It is frustrating. We've struggled to locate them. We just don't have the answers," he said.Just over an hour away, I see where they tried to cross into America, where two cities bear the same name - Nogales. This was the first place where a physical division between Mexico and America was built.Now, it is a 30ft (10m) mass of red, rusty, steel fencing.It's imposing - like a curtain cutting up the landscape and two communities either side.As we drive into the Mexico side, I'm surprised by what we see - a long line of people, queuing in 40-degree heat.Babies are sleeping on makeshift beds, as their parents try to get some food and water from a charity that are handing out basic supplies.I meet Kenya and her four-year-old son, Antobe. They have not eaten for days.She is pregnant and tells me she just spent 15 perilous days weaving her way here from Honduras."They are kidnapping children in my country," she says.Despite the massive barrier holding them back, some will try to climb over the fence that looms over this area or crawl under it.There are border patrol officers all along the route, but you can still spot t-shirts and bottles - the discarded detritus of what little immigrants had with them.As we are crossing back into the US, one border patrol officer says: "I'd never live close to here. It's just not safe."Those who break the law will often end up in detention centres in the desert.We drive around some of these facilities. They are sprawling, stark, inhospitable places.From there, they will be funnelled into the court where we started our day - the vast majority deported.Their children are being held in a number of undisclosed locations - some close by.At one, a police guard sits outside. No press, we are told, are allowed to film inside.In Casa Alitas shelter in Tucson, there is some hope for those who take the legal route in, a possible date to get their cases heard. In a crowded room, a group of bewildered looking asylum seekers are getting legal advice, travel tips and basic food and some clothing.They will have to travel to multiple states on buses in a country they have never seen and with very little money to their names.Eleven-year-old Yosmery cries as she tells me: "The only thing I want is to study here in America."Her mother says she is a victim of domestic violence, but under new rules, that does not automatically qualify her to stay.

title: new record as heatwave continues to bake parts of uk
story: Parts of north west England, Northern Ireland and Scotland could reach up to 30C or 31C on Thursday.Britain has been basking in sunshine as a heatwave continues across the country and the fine, hot weather is expected to stay into next month.Parts of the UK are hotter than Athens in Greece, and on a par with Kuala Lumpur in Malaysia and Rio de Janeiro in Brazil.The highest temperatures over the next few days are set to be in the north and west, rather than the South East.And there is a chance Northern Ireland will beat its highest-ever recorded temperature of 30.8C (87.4F). That mark was set on 30 June 1976 at Knockarevan in County Fermanagh and then equalled on 12 July 1983 at Shaw's Bridge, Belfast.Scotland could get close to its June record of 32.2C (89.9F), which was set way back on 18 June 1893 in Ochtertyre, Perth and Kinross.   Sky weather producer Chris England said: "It looks like there's about a 50% chance that somewhere in Northern Ireland will get over 30.8C in the next couple of days, beating the all-time temperature record set in 1976."Scotland's June record of 32.2C has a lower chance of being beaten, probably around 10%, but it is possible."He added: "It is also worth noting that Ireland's top temperature (both June and all-time) of 33.3C (91.9F) is highly unlikely to be broken." Public Health England has issued a warning saying the extreme heat may pose a risk to the most vulnerable.SCOTLAND:Hottest ever day: 32.9C (91.2F) on 9 August 2003 at Greycrook in the Scottish Borders.Hottest ever June: 32.2C (89.9F) on 18 June 1893 in Ochtertyre, Perth and Kinross. WALES:Hottest ever day: 35.2C (95.3F) on 2 August 1990 at Hawarden Bridge in Flintshire.Hottest ever June: 33.7C (38.6F) on 18 June 2000 in Machynlleth, Powys.NORTHERN IRELAND:

title: snarling tories pmqs stick two
story: NewsopinionSnarling Tories at PMQs stick two fingers up to ordinary Brits - Kevin Maguire's verdictThis week the wall of groans started when Jeremy Corbyn introduced Honda worker Andrew - showing Tory MPs' contempt for ordinary Brits&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor13:13, 27 JUN 2018Updated13:33, 27 JUN 2018NewsopinionVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSnarling Tory MPs jeering and sneering when Jeremy Corbyn introduces the problems and fears of people during Prime Minister's Questions is one side of Parliament sticking up two fingers at the country. This week the wall of groans started when he introduced Honda worker Andrew who is worried about his job in Swindon when the car industry fears Brexit will be a catastrophic crash for manufacturing. Corbyn exploited pretty well the warnings of industry giants such as BMW and Airbus that leaving the customs union is likely to cost investment and jobs yet the truth is he should've done better when business is revolting and Conservative Ministers are publicly attacking each other. Theresa May was her usual ineffective self but Corbyn should've shot more fish in the Tory Brexit barrel, failing to mock her and them mercilessly with the devastating contempt he deployed in previous weeks.

title: extraordinary life princess alice prince
story: NewsExtraordinary life of Princess Alice - Prince William's hero great grandmother who sheltered a Jewish family from the NazisPrincess Alice of Battenberg is honoured by the Jewish people for saving a family from Nazi persecution despite the risks to her own family's lives&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJulie McCaffrey17:56, 27 JUN 2018Updated18:57, 27 JUN 2018NewsPrincess Alice is buried in Israel (Image: TV Grab)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince William will make a poignant visit to his great grandmother's grave on the final day of his visit to Israel. Princess Alice of Battenberg, as she was known, requested her final resting place to be on Jerusalem’s Mount of Olives, a wish that was finally realised in 1988. Before her death in 1969, Alice, the mother of Prince Philip, had lived an extraordinary life, which included sheltering a Jewish widow and her two children in German-occupied Athens during the Second World War. She secretly ferried them food and messages of the war-torn outside world for 13 months. During his Middle East trip William spent time privately with Evy and Philippe Cohen, who told him how she had sheltered Evy's great grandmother Rachel Cohen and Rachel's daughter, Tilde, in Athens during the German occupation of Greece. Mr Cohen said: “We all owe our existence to her courage.” Philippe, 31, and Evy, 62, are descended from the sons of Rachel, who left Greece to join the resistance once they knew their mother and sister were safely hidden. Princess Alice has been honoured by the Jewish people for saving a family from Nazi persecution despite the risks to her own family's lives.  But hers was always destined to be a singular life and was, from the very start, extraordinary. She was born in the Tapestry Room of Windsor Castle in 1885 with her great-grandmother Queen Victoria in the room. Her father was the German Prince Louis and her mother a British princess - Victoria Mountbatten, Marchioness of Milford Haven - so Alice was related to most royal families in Europe. Aged eight Alice was diagnosed with deafness and learned to lip read. Relatives believed her deafness made her more empathetic and sensitive towards those who seemed isolated. In 1902 at the coronation of her cousin King Edward VII in London Alice met and fell in love with then Prince Andrew of Greece. When they married the following year she gained her second title, Princess Andrew of Greece and Denmark. The eldest of their five children is Prince Philip, William’s grandfather. But it was not to be a happy union.  After her husband was exiled from his native Greece to France, blamed for military failures in a war with Turkey between 1919-22, Alice’s marriage hit the buffers. She suffered a nervous breakdown and in 1930 was forcibly removed from her family and treated for schizophrenia in a Swiss mental institution. In that time her son, Prince Philip, moved to Britain to live with his uncles Louis and George Mountbatten. Her three daughters all married German princes who later fought with the Nazis but she did not attend their weddings. Alice never lived with her husband again and later settled alone in Greece, where she worked to help poor people. There she reconnected with old friend Haimaki Cohen, a Jewish member of the Greek Parliament, his wife Rachel, and their family. Sensing increasing anti-Semitism in Europe, she promised to help the Cohens if ever they needed aid. In 1943, as the Germans were rounding up Jews in Greece, Rachel was now widowed and desperately needed that help. Hearing of their plight, Alice hid Rachel, her daughter Tilde and later her son Michael in her small apartment. It was an extremely risky move, not least because the apartment was in the shadows of the Gestapo office in Athens. Princess Alice moved in to a separate building, where she worked as a caretaker, and trusted only a few people to help look after the Cohens. During the Nazi occupation of Athens in 1943, some assumed that Alice was pro-German. But when one general asked: “Is there anything I can do for you?” She replied: “You can take your troops out of my country.” In 1947 Princess Alice attended the wedding of her son Philip to Princess Elizabeth in London. Her three daughters were not invited because of the strong anti-German sentiment in the country .

title: running shadow wall what life
story: NewsRunning in the shadow of the wall: What life is like for Palestine's female marathon runnersFor female runners in war-torn Palestine, pounding the pavements comes with many challenges – from navigating checkpoints, refugee camps and watchtowers, to societal attitudes that say that woman shouldn't run at all...&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRosie Hopegood15:03, 27 JUN 2018News (Image: Right To Movement)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email   When nine Scottish runners took part in the Palestine Marathon in March, they found themselves running in a race like no other. The route, which snakes through the dusty streets of Bethlehem, passes watchtowers, refugee camps, and barbed wire fences. It weaves past checkpoints, piles of rubble, and the Church of Nativity, built on the spot where Jesus is supposed to have been born. Most notably of all, the route can only go 11km before it needs to double back on itself.  In war-torn Palestine, there isn’t a stretch of road longer than this that doesn't meet with a wall or one of Israeli government’s checkpoints.  Completing the full 42km marathon route therefore involves running back and forth along the same stretch of road, often in the shadow of the graffiti covered wall that runs 440 miles along the whole of the West Bank.  ‘We live in a city with borders we cannot escape,’ says Aseel Baidoun, a 28 year-old Palestinian runner. ‘In each direction you have a checkpoint, a settlement or an 8m high cement wall. It’s choking, and running feels like my only way to breathe.’ It’s this lack of freedom of movement that Scottish film-makers Cairsti Russell and Stephen Sheriff hope to highlight in a new documentary that aims to humanise the politically fraught situation in the West Bank. Working closely with Palestinian pressure group Right to Movement, the pair plan to bring the everyday struggles of Palestinians to a new audience.  At it’s heart, Freedom to Run will be a documentary about the friendship that blooms between a group of Scottish and Palestinian runners as they take part in two very different marathons: one in Palestine, and, two months later, one in Edinburgh.   ‘Of course, there is a huge disparity between life here and there,’ says Cairsti, who is currently studying for a PhD focusing on media coverage of the Israeli Palestine conflict. ‘But then at the same time there are so many ways that there is no disparity at all – we share so many similarities, and that was one of the important things I wanted to get across.’ It’s hard to imagine a marathon route that sits in more of a stark contrast to Palestine than Edinburgh. The Scottish capital’s famous route meanders gently past Georgian townhouses and treelined parks, along cherry blossom lined walkways and around the base of the famous inactive volcano Arthur’s Seat. ‘Running in Scotland was a bitter-sweet experience,’ says Aseel. ‘I was jealous of Scottish people, and kept asking myself why I hadn’t been born in Glasgow, where I can just wear my shorts and run. Life is so easy there, there’s nothing to worry about except the weather. Waking up in the morning, putting on shorts and jogging past trees, rivers, and grass is everything I could wish for.’  ‘In the West Bank, we don’t have parks, sea shores or forests to run in. We have the streets, that mostly lack sidewalks, so we run inhaling the smoke of cars. There’s no way to reach the sea or forests due to the checkpoints and separation wall that surrounds our city, and we can’t run in mountain tracks due to the settlements that are built there.’ It’s a fraught political situation: since the 1990s, the Israeli government has built hundreds of checkpoints and claim that they are needed to prevent Palestinian gunmen and suicide bombers from entering the country.  This month marks 51 years since the Israeli occupation of Gaza and the West Bank, with the current death toll from the ensuing conflict standing at more than 8,000.   The separation wall, built in 2000, was deemed illegal by the International Court of Justice in 2004, and, according to a report from human rights watchdog Amnesty International , it's prevented heavily pregnant women from making it to midwives, bridegrooms from attending their own weddings, and dying children from reaching hospitals in time.   Amnesty International UK Director Kate Allen says: 'Israel’s legitimate right to defend its people cannot justify imposing hundreds and hundreds of checkpoints on Palestinian land. Contrary to official claims about Israel’s overall “security” needs, the checkpoints and restricted West Bank roads appear to exist mainly for the benefit of Israel’s settlements, settlements that are themselves illegal under international law.' There are currently 522 of these checkpoints in use, and Palestinians are required to carry ID at all times. ‘The day before the Scottish marathon, we were getting ready to travel from Glasgow to Edinburgh,’ says Diala Isid, 28, who heads up Palestinian pressure group Right to Movement and took part in the both marathons. ‘One of the runners asked me if we should take our passports with us. Immediately without any thinking, I said yes, because in Palestine we always get stopped and checked by the Israeli soldiers. We can’t travel from any city to another without having our identification card so it just didn’t occur to me that we wouldn’t need them here either.’  Diala, like 4 out of 5 Palestinians, cannot remember a time before occupation, having grown up under a system that sees Israeli security forces exert control over 2.6 million Arabs living in the West Bank and Gaza. She's only ever known one set of laws for Palestinians, another for Israelis. For the Scottish runners, seeing the way that Palestinian runners’ lives were inhibited was a huge shock. On an early morning visit to the notorious Checkpoint 300, where thousands of Palestinians queue for hours in cramped conditions on their daily commute to East Jerusalem, the British runners were horrified to see how tough conditions are. ‘It’s horrible to see this,’ says Caitlin Brennan. ‘It reminds me of images you see from Calais where people are taking a once in a lifetime risk to try and completely change their lives, rather than something they have to do every single day.’  But there were also life-affirming moments on both trips, like seeing a Palestinian hip hop show together, being welcomed into people’s family homes, and hearing the crowds cheering on the Scottish flag. In Glasgow, a taxi driver refused to accept any money from the runners when he found out where they were from. The runners formed a tight bond, regularly chatting and comparing training notes over Skype. When Aseel got married in between the marathons, the other runners joked that the couple were having a running honeymoon. In Edinburgh, Aseel and her new husband Amir crossed the finish line together after Aseel found Amir about to give up on the side of the road.  Back home, life is tough for the newlyweds: Aseel has a Jerusalem ID which means she can visit the West Bank but needs to live in Jerusalem otherwise she’ll lose her residency. But Amir’s West Bank ID means he does not have access to Jerusalem. The forced separation placed a strain on their fledgling marriage, so to be together, they've chosen to live in Kufr Aqab. This small area of Jerusalem lies just outside the wall, and is home to 140,000 Palestinians living in cramped, substandard conditions – there's no waste removal and running water is available just twice a week. Many of the residents have mixed IDs like Aseel and Amir, and have chosen to live there as there is no other way for them to be together. It's a story that is all too common for Palestinians. ‘It’s not easy living like this daily,’ says Marwa Edkaidek, 28, part of the Jerusalem Running Community. ‘Every little step you need the proof that you are the son of this land, you need a permit to cross to the near city that’s only 30 minutes away from where you live. Palestinians want to live a peaceful life – when you see us protesting or throwing rocks on the news, it’s because we’ve reached breaking point.’ This isn’t the first project that Aseel and Diala have taken part in to raise awareness of the lack of freedom of movement in Palestine. In 2016, they ran in relay teams between Bethlehem and Nazavrus as part of Right to Movement’s #MaryCantMove campaign, aiming to highlight that Mary and Joseph wouldn’t have been able to make their famous journey today. Checkpoints aren't the only problem for the young women taking part in the marathon – there’s also a backlash from men in their community. A former UN marathon through the Gaza Strip was cancelled as Palestinian militant Islamist group Hamas wouldn’t not allow men and women to run together, and when Aseel started running back in 2014, she was one of just six female runners in the Ramallah community.  ‘My parents thought I was mad, and asked what I could possibly get out of running apart from nasty looks from people on the streets,’ she says. ‘But I get my freedom. We’ve had guys chasing us in cars, stalking us, and giving us disgusting comments. Even the reactions from the women can be negative – I remember once a young women saw us running and sarcastically commented, “Look at these girls they think they are in New York.” But we don’t care, we just carry on focusing on our breathing and our speed.' Slowly, attitudes to running are changing, particularly since the marathon was introduced five years ago. The film makers hope that the documentary will help to change perceptions, as well as raising awareness but the lack of freedom of movement faced by Palestinians on a daily basis. Film maker Cairsti has been left with more of a sense of what the runners have in common than that which differs between them.

title: bt disguises unsightly broadband box
story: NewsBT disguises 'unsightly' broadband box in ingenious way after villagers complained it was ruining picturesque streetThe BT Openreach cabinet was originally green in colour - but it now almost exactly matches a flint wall in the 650-year-old Suffolk village&nbspShare&nbspCommentsBySophie Evans10:16, 27 JUN 2018Updated15:38, 27 JUN 2018NewsBT has camouflaged the broadband box so it matches the flint wall behind it (Image: Anglian Press)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBT has disguised a broadband box in an ingenious way - after villagers complained it was ruining the picturesque area. The Openreach cabinet was originally green in colour when it was erected on a street in the 650-year-old village of Stanstead, Suffolk. But after locals complained that it looked so out of place, the company camouflaged the box to match the flint wall behind it. And the results are remarkable. At a quick glance, the 4ft tall, 4ft wide box is barely visible, with the printed material covering it an almost exact match with the wall.  Wall owner, Ervin Xhafa, who had contacted BT about the box in front of his 16th century home, said it now blends in much better. The 35-year-old property executive told The Sun :It is certainly an improvement and blends in much better with the street scene. But we would still rather that it was not there. BT teamed up with council officials to disguise the box. Graham Lee, acting chairman of the parish council, described seeing workers meticulously covering the box in the wall-themed material.  The result is remarkable - and full marks to BT and Openreach for going the extra mile to help what could be deemed as an unsightly metal box blend in to our village, he said. Another local praised the terrific work. But they claimed that while the stealthy cabinet looks great, they are still yet to be connected to faster broadband. Earlier this month, it emerged that BT is to replace its chief executive, Gavin Patterson, amid waning support for the company's trajectory.

title: eloise parry online steroid dealer
story: NewsEloise Parry: Online steroid dealer who sold toxic slimming pills which killed bulimic student GUILTY of manslaughterEloise Parry, 21, from Shrewsbury, died in April 2015 after taking tablets containing the poisonous Dinitrophenol (DNP)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter16:46, 27 JUN 2018Updated17:05, 27 JUN 2018NewsEloise Parry was bulimic and bought the pills online (Image: SWNS +44 (0)1179066550)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn online steroid dealer who sold toxic slimming pills which killed a bulimic student has been found guilty of manslaughter. Eloise Parry, 21, from Shrewsbury, died in hospital on April 12 2015 after taking eight tablets containing the poisonous Dinitrophenol (DNP). Bernard Rebelo, 31, from Gosport in Hampshire, was found guilty at Inner London Crown Court of two counts of manslaughter and one of placing unsafe food on the market. He will be sentenced on Friday. Rebelo admitted while giving evidence during the trial that he sold DNP to Miss Parry.  He told the jury that he included a warning on his website that the substance was not for human consumption. Rebelo's girlfriend Mary Roberts, 32, was cleared by the jury of one count of money laundering after she was accused of transferring &pound20,000 for and on behalf of Rebelo. Ms Roberts said she had never seen capsules for making pills where she lived and if she had she would have asked her partner Rebelo why they were there. She also said she had taken little interest in asking details of a business Rebelo had set up to sell muscle enhancing supplements and protein shakes. The couple wept in the dock as the verdicts were delivered on Wednesday afternoon, with Rebelo asking the judge: Can I see my daughter? Ms Roberts could be heard crying as the couple hugged one another. The jury had begun its deliberations on Tuesday afternoon.  Miss Parry died after taking eight diet pills containing the highly toxic DNP. Her sister Rebecca Parry, now aged 19, said in a statement read out during the trial that she had been focused on losing weight. She noted that in the weeks and months leading up to her death, her sister had struggled more and more with her eating disorder. She said: The diet pills she had taken had made her lose a drastic amount of weight but she still wanted to be slimmer. Rebecca Parry said she left Eloise's house on April 11 at about 9pm and that her sister, who had been talking about doing a Master's degree, seemed happy but tired. She had leg pain. Rebecca said: She mentioned a takeaway but I told her not to order one unless she was sure she could eat it.

title: horrified mum found ex flames
story: NewsHorrified mum 'found ex in flames outside front door before he collapsed, said "I love you" and died'WARNING: UPSETTING CONTENT Alan Graystone, 60, died after pouring petrol over himself and setting himself ablaze just two days after Christmas, an inquest heard today&nbspShareByJames CampbellSophie Evans14:07, 27 JUN 2018Updated16:32, 27 JUN 2018News (Image: Hull Daily Mail / MEN Media)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA horrified mum found her ex in flames outside her front door before he fell to his knees and said I love you, an inquest has heard. Alan Graystone, 60, died after pouring petrol over himself and setting himself ablaze just two days after Christmas, the hearing was told. He was discovered on fire by his shocked former partner who had noticed an orange glow outside her Hull home, Hull Live reports. Today, the woman told the inquest into Mr Graystone's death how the dad-of-four was not shouting or anything when she found him. She said she began screaming, What have you done?, before her ex-partner, who was facing her, fell to his knees and said I love you.  After finding Mr Graystone on fire on the night of December 27, the woman said she and her daughter tried to put out the flames. They used a pot of water and a water-soaked blanket, but the pub landlord was already black all over, the hearing was told. He sadly died at the scene, according to the news site. The coroner today concluded that Mr Graystone’s death was suicide, saying his actions were both premeditated and preplanned. The inquest, held at Hull Coroner's Court, heard he had left notes before he was discovered in flames shortly after 8pm. In a statement, heard at the court, Mr Graystone's ex-partner said the couple had been together for a while before splitting up in 2016.  She said they had lived together until 2017 due to the tenancy on the pub, the Blacksmith Arms, they ran together in Witham. Later that year, on December 27, she said an envelope was pushed through her door before she saw an orange glow outside. She then went to the door, moments after Mr Graystone had poured petrol over his body and set himself alight, the inquest heard. “Me and my daughter were in the house and I was preparing vegetables, the woman told the hearing. “My daughter said there was a letter from Alan with USB stick. He said it was all the photos of us. Another envelope was posted but I didn’t read it and heard him at the door.  “I then saw an orange glow through the frosted glass of the front door. I opened the door and Alan was facing me. He was on fire and covered in flames. “He was not shouting or anything. I started screaming and said ‘what have you done? What have you done? “He fell to his knees and I heard him say ‘I love you’.” Mr Graystone’s ex-partner’s daughter also recounted what happened that night, describing how the landlord tried to push himself up. She said: “I saw an orange glow and thought Alan had set the house on fire. Me and my mum opened the door at the same time. I looked to the left and saw Alan covered in flames from his head to his shins. I screamed ‘what have you done?’. “I heard him say ‘I love you’ and he fell to his hands and knees and then on to his stomach. He tried to push himself up and then he held his arms outstretched. “I went to get a bed sheet and wet it before throwing it over him. Everything seemed to happen in slow motion and I couldn’t seem to move my arms and legs quickly enough.”  She said she has still not come to terms with what happened. She said in a statement: “I have never been back to that address and I never will. What I saw that night will remain with me forever.” Mr Graystone's death came days after he had been arrested over an attack on his ex-partner's new boyfriend, the hearing heard. “In December my new partner was involved in an incident where bleach was thrown in his face, his former partner said. He had to have an operation and will need further operations. Alan was arrested and bailed, his ex-partner said. “Shortly before he died I saw him parked up at my place of work and he was crying. He said it was not him who did it but hoped I would get fed up of my partner and come back to home. “He said this would be the last time I see him and he would not bother me anymore.” Mr Graystone's brother, Kevin, had previously told the inquest how Alan had been in a series of failed relationships which made him depressed.

title: miss bumbum goes global brazils
story: NewsMiss Bumbum goes GLOBAL as Brazil's biggest beauty pageant expands to worldwide competitionMiss Bumbum World will carry the same rules as the Brazilian contest which prohibits participants who have undergone surgery to enlarge or enhance their bottoms&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMatt Roper16:38, 27 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWomen everywhere can now compete to be crowned Miss Bumbum after Brazil's biggest beauty pageant launched an international version of the contest. Miss Bumbum World will elect the best booty on the planet at a star-studded event in Miami in March next year, it was announced today. The competition's organisers said they decided to launch the global competition after receiving requests from women around the world asking to take part in the famous contest, which is now in its eight year in Brazil. Miss Bumbum World will carry the same rules as the Brazilian competition, which prohibits participants who have undergone surgery to enlarge or enhance their bums.  Registrations for contestants will open on December 1. But unlike the Brazil contest, which bans bottoms bigger than 107cm (42in) in diameter, there will be no limit on the size of contestants' bottoms, meaning Kim Kardashian's 109cm (43in) wide bottom could take part. For the global competition, one contestant will be chosen for each country, with no limit on the number of nations represented. During the live final in Miami next year, each participant will be marked by a panel of judges after shaking their bottoms in a free performance wearing an outfit inspired by their national dress, organisers said.  Announcing Miss Bumbum World, the competition’s creator Cacau Oliver yesterday released some of the hundreds of photos sent to him by would-be Miss Bumbums around the world. And he criticised the recent decision by Miss America to ban the swimwear portion from its pageant, saying that traditional beauty contests had become outdated. He said: Every year we receive emails and messages from women from all around the world. We have run some competitions outside of Brazil, and this year both Japan and Poland will have versions of the contest. Because of the number of women expressing their interest in taking part we decided to create Miss Bumbum World, which is a global version of the Brazilian competition. I think we’ll get thousands of entrants.  Anyone can take part, but we would prefer that each nation elects their own representative who will fight to prove that their country has the best bottom in the world. Cacau, the star of a new reality show in Brazil following his work promoting the Miss Bumbum brand, added: As people lose interest in other beauty pageants because they just show stereotypes, Miss Bumbum continues fascinate people around the world. Banning bikinis from their catwalks shows just how outdated Miss America and other beauty contests have become.

title: mum sues thomas cook after
story: NewsMum suing Thomas Cook after 'daughter, 5, abducted from hotel kids club in Turkey'Traumatised Janet Alexander, 46, feared her daughter Rose was 'either dead or trafficked' when she went missing from the Royal Wings Hotel in Antalya&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLucy Clarke-BillingsPaul Rodger11:32, 27 JUN 2018Updated12:44, 27 JUN 2018NewsJanet took Lois, nine, to a scuba lesson before returning to the club to find Rose, five, was missing (Image: Digby Brown / SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum is suing Thomas Cook after claiming her five-year-old daughter was abducted from a hotel kids club in Turkey. Janet Alexander, 46, claims her daughter Rose was taken by a stranger during a family holiday to the country in April. The senior charge nurse from Inverness says her youngest daughter was taken while at a supervised kids club at the Royal Wings Hotel in Antalya. After taking her eldest daughter Lois, nine, to a scuba lesson, Janet returned an hour later to discover Rose was missing. A frantic search for the child was then launched and Janet has described seeing staff turn to a woman in a hijab and speak to her in Turkish.  It is believed the ordeal came to an end 40 minutes later when another hotel guest spotted the blonde youngster walking with a woman in a hijab near a main road within the hotel grounds. Janet claims that hotel staff did not even know the girl was gone and when the staff failed to answer any questions Janet took her two daughters to the local police station. After speaking with an on-duty interpreter, Janet says police said they could not look into the matter as Rose was not physically harmed and had been returned safely. The P1 pupil was invited to go for a walk and thought it was okay as she remembered going for outside walks at pre-school.  The mother of two has now opened up about the experience - which she said is the most traumatic of my life. Janet said: I was completely distraught, completely. There was chaos as everybody realised she was missing and started running around and people from around the pool started looking for her. I was really quite frozen with fear. This has been the most traumatic experience of my life. I thought my daughter was either dead or faced being trafficked and abused. People need to realise these staff-led play groups aren't the safe places we believe them to be. I'll never trust Thomas Cook again.  Janet is now suing Thomas Cook over the alleged incident. The holiday in April this year was the first ever trip abroad for Janet and her daughters. The family was three days into a week-long break when the incident happened. Janet, a nurse with NHS Highland, remains shaken by the incident and hasn't been able to return to work due to suffering from extreme anxiety and post-traumatic stress. Janet has voiced her anger at Thomas Cook who she claims have not apologised for what went on.  She said: No matter how much I process things it just leaves me in pieces. I've been shaking and in tears ever since it happened - I even struggle to leave the kids at school now. My work, neighbours, family and friends have all been really supportive. Even though they couldn't do anything, the Turkish police were kind and sympathetic. But Thomas Cook have been a disgrace - they haven't apologised and have actually gone to great lengths to ignore me. What happened has changed our whole way of living and without even apology it's like I can't get closure and don't know how to heal. Janet has now launched a civil claim stating Thomas Cook failed to respond to repeated calls for help during and after the incident. She hopes the outcome will lead to improved safety standards.

title: prince louiss christening date significant
story: NewsWhy Prince Louis's christening will be extra special for his great-grandmother the QueenPrince Louis will be christening by Archbishop of Canterbury on July 9 - but the date is already very special to his great-grandmother the Queen&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer15:29, 27 JUN 2018Updated15:34, 27 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt's been a very busy year for the royal family with two new royal babies, a royal engagement and of course a rather important wedding.  But the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and the rest of the gang are now getting ready for the next big occasion - Prince Louis's christening .  The Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Reverend Justin Welby, will take the service, which will be held at the Chapel Royal in St James’s Palace. The date to pop in your diary is July 9 - but that day is already a very important one for the Queen.  Go back 71 years and July 9 is the date her majesty, who was then Princess Elizabeth, announced she was engaged to Philip Mountbatten. Even though they were privately engaged for a year before, they didn't make it public until July 9, 1947. They made the announcement at Buckingham Palace. As is traditional in the royal family, they also released an official photo to mark the occassion. It shows Elizabeth sitting on a chair with Philip sitting on the arm, and they are staring into each others eyes looking very much in love.  The couple married later that year at Westminster Abbey and became the Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh. As we all remember from Prince William and Harry's engagement announcements, it's a big day for any royal so it's probably still a special day for the Queen. Her majesty is due to attended to attend Louis's christening, and it's expected that Prince Philip will be by her side despite retiring from royal duties last year.

title: sweet meaning behind zara mike
story: NewsThe sweet meaning behind Zara and Mike Tindall's new baby daughter's nameZara and Mike Tindall welcomed their second child, a baby girl, earlier this month but they've kept us waiting for the name&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer17:06, 27 JUN 2018Updated17:14, 27 JUN 2018NewsThe couple have picked a lovely name (Image: WENN)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Zara and Mike Tindall have finally revealed their new baby girl's name - Lena Elizabeth.  Unlike other members of the royal family, they stayed clear of traditional regal names and picked something a bit more unusual. According to the couple's spokesman, they picked the name simply because it is just a name they liked. But there is actually a lovely meaning behind the name, which is pronounced Lay-na.  Lena is the Greek word for 'light'. So far this year it has been the 279th most popular girl name, 15 places up from last year. However it's far from a modern name, and it was extremely popular centuries ago.  In terms of popularity, it reached its peak in 1885, when about 6,584 of every million babies were given the name, reports parenting website BabyCentre .   She also shares the name with lots of celebs, including Game of Thrones star Lena Headey and American actress Lena Dunham.  The baby girl's middle name is Elizabeth, which is likely a tribute to her great-grandmother the Queen.  She shares the middle name with her cousin Prince Charlotte. The new arrival, the second royal baby this year after Prince Louis, is the Queen and Prince Philip's seventh great-grandchild. Little Lena made history by becoming the heaviest ever royal baby, weighing 9lbs and 3oz. She will be a little sister for the couple's first daughter Mia.  Zara and Mike waited several days to reveal the name, which experts believe is because they needed to tell the Queen the name before they told anyone else. Lena was born at Stroud Maternity Unit in Gloucestershire on Monday, June 18. The royal family released a statement to reveal the news, which read: Mrs Michael Tindall was safely delivered of a baby girl on 18th June, at Stroud Maternity Unit.
